issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Pneumatic.raisePressure(pressure: double): void (a double parameter), but the solution uses an int parameter (raisePressure(int)). This mismatch between the specified interface signature and the solution's implementation is a structural inconsistency. Students following the UML will declare raisePressure(double) while the reference implementation (and its implementing classes) use raisePressure(int), which can cause confusion and make it unclear which signature is intended.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the raisePressure parameter type across all artifacts. Update the interface and all implementing methods to use the same parameter type as specified in the UML. Preferably change the solution (and template skeleton) to match the problem statement: declare raisePressure(double pressure) in Pneumatic and implement raisePressure(double) in LaunchedDropdownTower and LaunchedRollerCoaster. Alternatively, if int is intended, update the problem statement UML to show an int parameter instead of double.

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Pneumatic.raisePressure(pressure: double) (problem_statement.md, UML lines), while the solution (and the problem's textual remark) use an int parameter named pressureIncrease (solution_repository/src/de/tum/in/ase/Pneumatic.java). This creates a mismatch in the expected parameter type and name for the same conceptual operation (raising pneumatic pressure). Students reading the UML will expect a double-typed parameter named pressure, but the provided solution and remark refer to an int-typed parameter pressureIncrease, causing unnecessary confusion about the correct method signature to implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the raisePressure signature consistent across all artifacts. Either (A) update the UML in problem_statement.md to declare raisePressure(pressureIncrease: int): void (and adjust the textual remark to match), or (B) change the solution and remark to use double (raisePressure(double pressure)). Also harmonize the parameter name (e.g., pressure or pressureIncrease) across problem, template, and solution so students see the same signature everywhere.
